CHARGED EXOTIC CHARMONIUM STATES

MARINA NIELSEN Instituto de F√≠sica, Universidade de S√£o Paulo

Abstract

In this short review we present and discuss all the experimental information about the charged exotic charmonium states, which have been observed over the last five years. We try to understand their properties such as masses and decay widths with QCD sum rules. We describe this method, show the results and compare them with the experimental data and with other theoretical approaches.

keywords:
exotic states; non-perturbative methods.

1 Introduction

Since its first observation in 2003 by the Belle Collaboration [1], the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) has attracted the interest of all the hadronic community. It is the most well studied state among the new charmonium states and has been confirmed by five collaborations: CDF [2], D0 [3], BaBar [4], LHCb [5] and CMS [6]. There is little doubt in the community that the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) structure is more complex than just a c‚Äãc¬Øùëê¬Øùëêc\bar{c} state. Besides the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) the other recently observed charmonium states that clearly have a more complex structure than c‚Äãc¬Øùëê¬Øùëêc\bar{c} are the charged states. Up to now there are some experimental evidences for seven charged states, which are shown in Table 1.

The first charged charmonium state, the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430), was observed by the Belle Collaboration in 2008, produced in B+‚ÜíK‚Äã(œà‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÄ+)‚Üísuperscriptùêµùêæsuperscriptùúì‚Ä≤superscriptùúãB^{+}\to K(\psi^{\prime}\pi^{+}) [7]. However the Babar Collaboration [8] searched for the Z‚àí‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{-}(4430) signature in four decay modes and concluded that there is no significant evidence for a signal peak in any of these processes. Very recently the Belle Collaboration has confirmed the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) observation and has determined the preferred assignment of the quantum numbers to be JP=1+1superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript11J^{P}=1^{+1} [9]. Curiously, there are no reports of a Z+superscriptùëçZ^{+} signal in the J/œà‚ÄãœÄ+ùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãJ/\psi\pi^{+} decay channel.

The Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) observation motivated further studies of other B¬Ø0superscript¬Øùêµ0\bar{B}^{0} decays. The Belle Collaboration has reported the observation of two resonance-like structures, called Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) and Z2+‚Äã(4250)superscriptsubscriptùëç24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250), in the exclusive process B¬Ø0‚ÜíK‚àí‚ÄãœÄ+‚Äãœác‚Äã1‚Üísuperscript¬Øùêµ0superscriptùêæsuperscriptùúãsubscriptùúíùëê1\bar{B}^{0}\to K^{-}\pi^{+}\chi_{c1}, in the œÄ+‚Äãœác‚Äã1superscriptùúãsubscriptùúíùëê1\pi^{+}\chi_{c1} mass distribution [10]. Once again the BaBar colaboration did not confirm these observations [11].

After these non confirmations, it was with great excitement that the hadron community heard about the observation of the Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900). The Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) was first observed by the BESIII collaboration in the (œÄ¬±‚ÄãJ/œà)superscriptùúãplus-or-minusùêΩùúì(\pi^{\pm}J/\psi) mass spectrum of the Y‚Äã(4260)‚ÜíJ/œà‚ÄãœÄ+‚ÄãœÄ‚àí‚Üíùëå4260ùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãsuperscriptùúãY(4260)\to J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-} decay channel [12]. This structure, was also observed at the same time by the Belle collaboration [13] and was confirmed by the authors of Ref. ¬†[\refciteXiao:2013iha] using CLEO-c data.

Soon after the Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) observation, the BESIII related the observation of other three charges states: Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) [15], Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) [16] and Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) [17]. Up to now it is not clear if the states Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900)-Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) and the states Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025)-Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) are the same states seen in different decay channels, or if they are independent states.

All these charged states can not be c‚Äãc¬Øùëê¬Øùëêc\bar{c} states and they are natural candidates for molecular or tetraquark states. These exotic states are allowed by the strong interactions, both at the fundamental level and at the effective level, and their absence in the experimentally measured spectrum has always been a mystery. The theoretical tools to address these questions are lattice QCD, chiral perturbation theory, QCD sum rules (QCDSR), effective lagrangian approaches and quark models. For more details we refer the reader to the more comprehensive Ref.¬†[\refcitenora] and to the more recent and also more specific Ref.¬†[\refcitereliu] review articles.

In this rapidly evolving field, periodic accounts of the status of theory and experiment are needed. There are already several reviews of the recent charmonium spectroscopy. The present one is focused on the charged states and on the QCDSR approach to them. In the next sections we discuss some of these new charmonium states using the QCDSR approach.

2 QCD Sum Rules

The method of the QCDSR is a powerful tool to evaluate the masses and decay widths of hadrons based on first principles. It was first introduced by Shifman, Vainshtein and Zakharov [20] to the study of mesons, and was latter extended to baryons by Ioffe [21] and Chung et al. [22, 23]. Since then the QCDSR technique has been applied to study numerous hadronic properties with various flavor content and has been discussed in many reviews [24, 25, 26, 27, 28] emphasizing different aspects of the method. The method is based on identities between two- or three-point correlation functions, which connect hadronic observables with QCD fundamental parameters, such as quark masses, the strong coupling constant, and quantities which characterize the QCD vacuum, i.e., the condensates. The correlation function is of a dual nature: it represents a quark-antiquark fluctuation for short distances (or large momentum) and can be treated in perturbative QCD, while at large distances (or small momentum) it can be related to hadronic observables. The sum rule calculations are based on the assumption that in some range of momentum both descriptions are equivalent. One, thus, proceeds by calculating the correlation function for both cases and by eventually equating them to obtain information on the properties of the hadrons.

In principle, QCDSR allow first-principle calculations. In practice, however, in order to extract results, it is necessary to make expansions, truncations, and other approximations that may reduce the power of the formalism and introduce large errors. However, if one can find ways to control these errors, the method can provide important informations about the structure of the hadrons.

2.1 Hadron masses

The QCD sum rule calculations of the mass of a hadronic state are based on the correlator of two hadronic currents. A generic two-point correlation function is given by

Œ†‚Äã(q)‚â°i‚Äã‚à´d4‚Äãx‚Äãei‚Äãq‚ãÖx‚Äã‚ü®0|T‚Äã[j‚Äã(x)‚Äãj‚Ä†‚Äã(0)]|0‚ü©,Œ†ùëûùëñsuperscriptùëë4ùë•superscriptùëí‚ãÖùëñùëûùë•quantum-operator-product0ùëádelimited-[]ùëóùë•superscriptùëó‚Ä†00\Pi(q)\equiv i\int d^{4}x\,e^{iq\cdot x}\langle{0}|T[j(x)j^{\dagger}(0)]|0\rangle\ , (1)

where j‚Äã(x)ùëóùë•j(x) is a current with the quantum numbers of the hadron we want to study. In the QCDSR approach the correlation function is evaluated in two different ways: at the quark level in terms of quark and gluon fields and at the hadronic level introducing hadron characteristics such as the mass and the coupling of the hadronic state to the current j‚Äã(x)ùëóùë•j(x).

The hadronic side, or phenomenological side of the sum rule is evaluated by writing a dispersion relation to the correlator in Eq.¬†(1):

Œ†p‚Äãh‚Äãe‚Äãn‚Äã(q2)=‚àí‚à´ùëës‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã(s)q2‚àís+i‚Äãœµ+‚ãØ,superscriptŒ†ùëù‚Ñéùëíùëõsuperscriptùëû2differential-dùë†ùúåùë†superscriptùëû2ùë†ùëñitalic-œµ‚ãØ\Pi^{phen}(q^{2})=-\int ds\,{\rho(s)\over q^{2}-s+i\epsilon}\,+\,\cdots\,, (2)

where œÅùúå\rho is the spectral density given by the absorptive part of the correlator and the dots represent subtraction terms.

Since the current j‚Äã(j‚Ä†)ùëósuperscriptùëó‚Ä†j~{}(j^{\dagger}) is an operator that annihilates (creates) all hadronic states that have the same quantum numbers as jùëój, Œ†‚Äã(q)Œ†ùëû\Pi(q) contains information about all these hadronic states, including the low mass hadron of interest. In order the QCDSR technique to be useful, one must parameterize œÅ‚Äã(s)ùúåùë†\rho(s) with a small number of parameters. In general one parameterizes the spectral density as a single sharp pole representing the lowest resonance of mass mùëöm, plus a smooth continuum representing higher mass states:

Œ†p‚Äãh‚Äãe‚Äãn‚Äã(q2)=‚àíŒª2q2‚àím2‚àí‚à´sm‚Äãi‚Äãn‚àûùëës‚ÄãœÅc‚Äão‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äã(s)q2‚àís+i‚Äãœµ+‚ãØ,superscriptŒ†ùëù‚Ñéùëíùëõsuperscriptùëû2superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùëû2superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë†ùëöùëñùëõdifferential-dùë†subscriptùúåùëêùëúùëõùë°ùë†superscriptùëû2ùë†ùëñitalic-œµ‚ãØ\Pi^{phen}(q^{2})=-{\lambda^{2}\over q^{2}-m^{2}}\,-\,\int_{s_{min}}^{\infty}ds\,{\rho_{cont}(s)\over q^{2}-s+i\epsilon}\,+\,\cdots\,, (4)

In the QCD side, or OPE side the correlation function is evaluated by using the Wilson‚Äôs operator product expansion (OPE) [29]:

Œ†O‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(q)=‚àënCn‚Äã(Q2)‚ÄãO^n,superscriptŒ†ùëÇùëÉùê∏ùëûsubscriptùëõsubscriptùê∂ùëõsuperscriptùëÑ2subscript^ùëÇùëõ\Pi^{OPE}(q)=\sum_{n}C_{n}(Q^{2})\hat{O}_{n}\;, (5)

where the set {O^n}subscript^ùëÇùëõ\{\hat{O}_{n}\} includes all local gauge invariant operators expressible in terms of the gluon fields and the fields of light quarks, which are represented in the form of vacuum condensates. The lowest dimension condensates are the quark condensate of dimension three: O^3=‚ü®q¬Ø‚Äãq‚ü©subscript^ùëÇ3delimited-‚ü®‚ü©¬Øùëûùëû\hat{O}_{3}=\langle\bar{q}q\rangle, and the gluon condensate of dimension four: O^4=‚ü®g2‚ÄãG2‚ü©subscript^ùëÇ4delimited-‚ü®‚ü©superscriptùëî2superscriptùê∫2\hat{O}_{4}=\langle g^{2}G^{2}\rangle. The lowest-dimension operator with n=0ùëõ0n=0 is the unit operator associated with the perturbative contribution.

For non exotic mesons, i.e. normal quark-antiquark states, such as œÅùúå\rho and J/œàùêΩùúìJ/\psi, the contributions of condensates with dimension higher than four are suppressed by large powers of 1/Q21superscriptùëÑ21/Q^{2}. Therefore, the expansion in Eq.¬†(5) can be safely truncated after dimension four condensates, even at intermediate values of Q2(‚àº1‚ÄãGeV2)annotatedsuperscriptùëÑ2similar-toabsent1superscriptGeV2Q^{2}~{}(\sim 1\nobreak\,\mbox{GeV}^{2}). However, for molecular or tetraquark states, higher dimension condensates like the dimension five mixed-condensate: O^5=‚ü®q¬ØgœÉ.Gq‚ü©\hat{O}_{5}=\langle\bar{q}g\sigma.Gq\rangle, the dimension six four-quark condensate: O^6=‚ü®q¬Ø‚Äãq‚Äãq¬Ø‚Äãq‚ü©subscript^ùëÇ6delimited-‚ü®‚ü©¬Øùëûùëû¬Øùëûùëû\hat{O}_{6}=\langle\bar{q}q\bar{q}q\rangle and even the dimension eight quark condensate times the mixed-condensate: O^8=‚ü®q¬Øqq¬ØgœÉ.Gq‚ü©\hat{O}_{8}=\langle\bar{q}q\bar{q}g\sigma.Gq\rangle, can play an important role. The three-gluon condensate of dimension-six: O^6=‚ü®g3‚ÄãG3‚ü©subscript^ùëÇ6delimited-‚ü®‚ü©superscriptùëî3superscriptùê∫3\hat{O}_{6}=\langle g^{3}G^{3}\rangle can be safely neglected, since it is suppressed by the loop factor 1/16‚ÄãœÄ2116superscriptùúã21/16\pi^{2}.

The precise evaluation of the D=6ùê∑6D=6, O^6subscript^ùëÇ6\hat{O}_{6}, and D=8ùê∑8D=8, O^8subscript^ùëÇ8\hat{O}_{8}, condensates require a involved analysis including a non-trivial choice of factorization scheme [30]. Therefore, in our calculations we assume that their vacuum saturation values are given by:

‚ü®q¬Øqq¬Øq‚ü©=‚ü®q¬Øq‚ü©2,‚ü®q¬Øqq¬ØgœÉ.Gq‚ü©=‚ü®q¬Øq‚ü©‚ü®q¬ØgœÉ.Gq‚ü©.\langle\bar{q}q\bar{q}q\rangle=\langle\bar{q}q\rangle^{2},\;\;\;\langle\bar{q}q\bar{q}g\sigma.Gq\rangle=\langle\bar{q}q\rangle\langle\bar{q}g\sigma.Gq\rangle. (6)

The OPE side can also be written in terms of a dispersion relation as:

Œ†O‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(q2)=‚àí‚à´sm‚Äãi‚Äãn‚àûùëës‚ÄãœÅO‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(s)q2‚àís+i‚Äãœµ+‚ãØ,superscriptŒ†ùëÇùëÉùê∏superscriptùëû2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë†ùëöùëñùëõdifferential-dùë†superscriptùúåùëÇùëÉùê∏ùë†superscriptùëû2ùë†ùëñitalic-œµ‚ãØ\Pi^{OPE}(q^{2})=-\int_{s_{min}}^{\infty}ds\,{\rho^{OPE}(s)\over q^{2}-s+i\epsilon}\,+\,\cdots\,, (7)

where

œÅO‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(s)=1œÄ‚ÄãI‚Äãm‚Äã[Œ†O‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(s)].superscriptùúåùëÇùëÉùê∏ùë†1ùúãùêºùëödelimited-[]superscriptŒ†ùëÇùëÉùê∏ùë†\rho^{OPE}(s)={1\over\pi}Im[\Pi^{OPE}(s)]\;. (8)

To keep the number of parameters as small as possible, in general in the QCDSR approach one assumes that the continuum contribution to the spectral density, œÅc‚Äão‚Äãn‚Äãt‚Äã(s)subscriptùúåùëêùëúùëõùë°ùë†\rho_{cont}(s) in Eq.¬†(4), vanishes bellow a certain continuum threshold s0subscriptùë†0s_{0}. Above this threshold one uses the ansatz

Using Eq.¬†(9) in Eq.¬†(4) we get

Œ†p‚Äãh‚Äãe‚Äãn‚Äã(q2)=‚àíŒª2q2‚àím2‚àí‚à´s0‚àûùëës‚ÄãœÅO‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(s)q2‚àís+i‚Äãœµ+‚ãØ,superscriptŒ†ùëù‚Ñéùëíùëõsuperscriptùëû2superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùëû2superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë†0differential-dùë†superscriptùúåùëÇùëÉùê∏ùë†superscriptùëû2ùë†ùëñitalic-œµ‚ãØ\Pi^{phen}(q^{2})=-{\lambda^{2}\over q^{2}-m^{2}}\,-\,\int_{s_{0}}^{\infty}ds\,{\rho^{OPE}(s)\over q^{2}-s+i\epsilon}\,+\,\cdots\,, (10)

To improve the matching of the two descriptions of the correlator one applies the Borel transformation. The Borel transformation removes the subtraction terms in the dispersion relation, and exponentially suppresses the contribution from excited resonances and continuum states in the phenomenological side. In the OPE side the Borel transformation suppresses the contribution from higher dimension condensates by a factorial term.

After performing a Borel transform on both sides of the sum rule, and transferring the continuum contribution to the OPE side, the sum rule can be written as

Œª2‚Äãe‚àím2/M2=‚à´sm‚Äãi‚Äãns0ùëës‚Äãe‚àís/M2‚ÄãœÅO‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(s).superscriptùúÜ2superscriptùëísuperscriptùëö2superscriptùëÄ2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë†ùëöùëñùëõsubscriptùë†0differential-dùë†superscriptùëíùë†superscriptùëÄ2superscriptùúåùëÇùëÉùê∏ùë†\lambda^{2}e^{-m^{2}/M^{2}}=\int_{s_{min}}^{s_{0}}ds~{}e^{-s/M^{2}}~{}\rho^{OPE}(s)\;. (11)

A good sum rule is obtained in the case that one can find a range of M2superscriptùëÄ2M^{2}, called Borel window, in which the two sides have a good overlap and information on the lowest resonance can be extracted. To determine the allowed Borel window, one analyses the OPE convergence and the pole contribution: the minimum value of the Borel mass is fixed by considering the convergence of the OPE, and the maximum value of the Borel mass is determined by imposing the condition that the pole contribution must be bigger than the continuum contribution.

The mass of the hadronic state, mùëöm, can be obtained by taking the derivative of Eq.¬†(11) with respect to 1/M21superscriptùëÄ21/M^{2}, and dividing the result by Eq.¬†(11):

m2=‚à´sm‚Äãi‚Äãns0ùëës‚Äãe‚àís/M2‚Äãs‚ÄãœÅO‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(s)‚à´sm‚Äãi‚Äãns0ùëës‚Äãe‚àís/M2‚ÄãœÅO‚ÄãP‚ÄãE‚Äã(s).superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë†ùëöùëñùëõsubscriptùë†0differential-dùë†superscriptùëíùë†superscriptùëÄ2ùë†superscriptùúåùëÇùëÉùê∏ùë†superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùë†ùëöùëñùëõsubscriptùë†0differential-dùë†superscriptùëíùë†superscriptùëÄ2superscriptùúåùëÇùëÉùê∏ùë†m^{2}={\int_{s_{min}}^{s_{0}}ds~{}e^{-s/M^{2}}~{}s~{}\rho^{OPE}(s)\over\int_{s_{min}}^{s_{0}}ds~{}e^{-s/M^{2}}~{}\rho^{OPE}(s)}\;. (12)

Using the formalism described above we can compute the masses of the new states. A compilation of results of the states discussed here is shown in Table 2. These numbers will be discussed in detail in the next sections.

2.2 Hadron decay widths

The QCD sum rule calculations for the coupling constant in a hadronic vertex are based on the correlator of three hadronic currents. A generic three-point correlation function associated with a vertex of three mesons M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1}, M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} and M3subscriptùëÄ3M_{3} is given by

Œì‚Äã(p,p‚Ä≤,q)=‚à´d4‚Äãx‚Äãd4‚Äãy‚Äãei‚Äãp‚Ä≤‚ãÖx‚Äãe‚àíi‚Äãq‚ãÖy‚Äã‚ü®0|T‚Äã{j3‚Äã(x)‚Äãj2‚Ä†‚Äã(y)‚Äãj1‚Ä†‚Äã(0)}|0‚ü©Œìùëùsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùëûsuperscriptùëë4ùë•superscriptùëë4ùë¶superscriptùëí‚ãÖùëñsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùë•superscriptùëí‚ãÖùëñùëûùë¶quantum-operator-product0ùëásubscriptùëó3ùë•superscriptsubscriptùëó2‚Ä†ùë¶superscriptsubscriptùëó1‚Ä†00\Gamma(p,p^{\prime},q)=\int d^{4}x\,d^{4}y\;\;e^{ip^{\prime}\cdot x}\,e^{-iq\cdot y}\langle 0|T\{j_{3}(x)j_{2}^{\dagger}(y)j_{1}^{\dagger}(0)\}|0\rangle\, (13)

where q=p‚Ä≤‚àípùëûsuperscriptùëù‚Ä≤ùëùq=p^{\prime}-p and the current jisubscriptùëóùëñj_{i} represents states with the quantum numbers of the meson iùëñi. As in the case of the two-point correlation function, the function in Eq.¬†(13) is evaluated in two ways. In the OPE side we consider that the currents are composed by quarks and we use the Wilson‚Äôs OPE to evaluate the correlation function. In the phenomenological side, we insert, in Eq.(13), intermediate states for the mesons M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1}, M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} and M3subscriptùëÄ3M_{3}. We then write the correlation function in terms of the coupling of these mesons with the corresponding currents, and in terms of the form factor, gM1‚ÄãM2‚ÄãM3‚Äã(q2)subscriptùëîsubscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ3superscriptùëû2g_{M_{1}M_{2}M_{3}}(q^{2}), in the hadronic vertex, which is defined by the generalization of the on-mass-shell matrix element, ‚ü®M3‚ÄãM2|M1‚ü©inner-productsubscriptùëÄ3subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1\langle M_{3}M_{2}|M_{1}\rangle, for an off-shell M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} meson:

‚ü®M3‚Äã(p‚Ä≤)‚ÄãM2‚Äã(q)|M1‚Äã(p)‚ü©=gM1‚ÄãM2‚ÄãM3‚Äã(q2)‚ÄãfM1,p‚ÄãfM2,p‚Ä≤‚ÄãfM3,q,inner-productsubscriptùëÄ3superscriptùëù‚Ä≤subscriptùëÄ2ùëûsubscriptùëÄ1ùëùsubscriptùëîsubscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ3superscriptùëû2subscriptùëìsubscriptùëÄ1ùëùsubscriptùëìsubscriptùëÄ2superscriptùëù‚Ä≤subscriptùëìsubscriptùëÄ3ùëû\langle M_{3}(p^{\prime})M_{2}(q)|M_{1}(p)\rangle=g_{M_{1}M_{2}M_{3}}(q^{2})f_{M_{1},p}f_{M_{2},p^{\prime}}f_{M_{3},q}, (14)

which can be extracted from the effective Lagrangian that describes the coupling between these three mesons. In Eq.¬†(14) the functions fMi,ksubscriptùëìsubscriptùëÄùëñùëòf_{M_{i},k} are obained from the Lagrangian and are related with the quantum numbers of the meson MisubscriptùëÄùëñM_{i}. After evaluating both sides separately, we equate one description with the other and we can extract the form factor from the sum rule.

The coupling constant is defined as the value of the form factor at the meson pole: Q2=‚àím22superscriptùëÑ2superscriptsubscriptùëö22Q^{2}=-m_{2}^{2}, where m2subscriptùëö2m_{2} is the mass of the meson M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} that was off-shell. Very often, in order to determine the coupling constant we have to extrapolate the QCDSR results to a Q2superscriptùëÑ2Q^{2} region where the sum rules are no longer valid (since the QCDSR results are valid in the deep Euclidian region). To do that, in general, we parametrize the QCDSR results through a analytical form, like a monopole or an exponential function. For more details we refer the reader to Ref.¬†[\refciteBracco:2011pg].

3 X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872)

The X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) was first observed by Belle collaboration in 2003 in the decay B+‚ÜíX‚Äã(3872)‚ÄãK+‚ÜíJ/œà‚ÄãœÄ+‚ÄãœÄ‚àí‚ÄãK+‚Üísuperscriptùêµùëã3872superscriptùêæ‚ÜíùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãsuperscriptùúãsuperscriptùêæB^{+}\!\rightarrow\!X(3872)K^{+}\rightarrow\!J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-}K^{+} [1], and has been confirmed by other five collaborations [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. The current world average mass is mX=(3871.68¬±0.17)subscriptùëöùëãplus-or-minus3871.680.17m_{X}=(3871.68\pm 0.17) MeV and its total width is less than 1.21.21.2 MeV [32]. The LHCb collaboration determined JP‚ÄãC=1++superscriptùêΩùëÉùê∂superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++} quantum numbers with more than 8œÉùúé\sigma significance [33].

3.1 Mass

Calculations using constituent quark models give masses for possible charmonium states, with JP‚ÄãC=1++superscriptùêΩùëÉùê∂superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++} quantum numbers, which are much bigger than the observed X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) mass: 2‚ÄãP13‚Äã(3990)2superscriptsubscriptùëÉ1339902~{}^{3}P_{1}(3990) and 3‚ÄãP13‚Äã(4290)3superscriptsubscriptùëÉ1342903~{}^{3}P_{1}(4290) [34]. These results, together with the coincidence between the XùëãX mass and the D‚àó0‚ÄãD0superscriptùê∑absent0superscriptùê∑0D^{*0}D^{0} threshold: M‚Äã(D‚àó0‚ÄãD0)=(3871.81¬±0.36)‚ÄãMeVùëÄsuperscriptùê∑absent0superscriptùê∑0plus-or-minus3871.810.36MeVM(D^{*0}D^{0})=(3871.81\pm 0.36)\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV} [35], inspired the proposal that the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) could be a molecular (D‚àó0‚ÄãD¬Ø0+D¬Ø‚àó0‚ÄãD0)superscriptùê∑absent0superscript¬Øùê∑0superscript¬Øùê∑absent0superscriptùê∑0(D^{*0}\bar{D}^{0}+\bar{D}^{*0}D^{0}) bound state with small binding energy [36, 37, 38, 39, 40].

Other interesting possible interpretation of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872), first proposed by Maiani et al. [41], is that it could be a tetraquark state resulting from the binding of a diquark and an antidiquark.

The fisrt QCDSR calculation of the mass of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) considered as a JP‚ÄãC=1++superscriptùêΩùëÉùê∂superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++} tetraquark state was done in Ref.¬†[\refcitex3872]. Following this calculation, a JP‚ÄãC=1++superscriptùêΩùëÉùê∂superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++}, D‚àó‚ÄãD¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øùê∑D^{*}\bar{D} molecular current was considered in Ref.¬†[\refcitekorea]. The corresponding interpolating currents used in these calculations are:

jŒºd‚Äãisubscriptsuperscriptùëóùëëùëñùúá\displaystyle j^{di}_{\mu} =\displaystyle= i‚Äãœµa‚Äãb‚Äãc‚Äãœµd‚Äãe‚Äãc2‚Äã[(qaT‚ÄãC‚ÄãŒ≥5‚Äãcb)‚Äã(q¬Ød‚ÄãŒ≥Œº‚ÄãC‚Äãc¬ØeT)+(qaT‚ÄãC‚ÄãŒ≥Œº‚Äãcb)‚Äã(q¬Ød‚ÄãŒ≥5‚ÄãC‚Äãc¬ØeT)],ùëñsubscriptitalic-œµùëéùëèùëêsubscriptitalic-œµùëëùëíùëê2delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëûùëéùëáùê∂subscriptùõæ5subscriptùëêùëèsubscript¬Øùëûùëësubscriptùõæùúáùê∂superscriptsubscript¬Øùëêùëíùëásuperscriptsubscriptùëûùëéùëáùê∂subscriptùõæùúásubscriptùëêùëèsubscript¬Øùëûùëësubscriptùõæ5ùê∂superscriptsubscript¬Øùëêùëíùëá\displaystyle{i\epsilon_{abc}\epsilon_{dec}\over\sqrt{2}}[(q_{a}^{T}C\gamma_{5}c_{b})(\bar{q}_{d}\gamma_{\mu}C\bar{c}_{e}^{T})+(q_{a}^{T}C\gamma_{\mu}c_{b})(\bar{q}_{d}\gamma_{5}C\bar{c}_{e}^{T})]\;, (15)

for a tetraquark current, and

for a molecular D‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àóùê∑superscript¬Øùê∑D\bar{D}^{*} current. In Eqs.¬†(15) and (16), qùëûq denotes a uùë¢u or dùëëd quark.

In the OPE side, the calculations were done at leading order in Œ±ssubscriptùõºùë†\alpha_{s} and contributions of condensates up to dimension eight were included. In both cases it was possible to find a Borel window where the pole contribution is bigger than the continuum contribution and with a reasonable OPE convergence.

The mass obtained in Ref.¬†[\refcitex3872], considering the allowed Borel window and the uncertaities in the parameters, was mX=(3.92¬±0.13)subscriptùëöùëãplus-or-minus3.920.13m_{X}=(3.92\pm 0.13) GeV whereas the result for the mass obtained in Ref.¬†[\refcitekorea] was mX=(3.87¬±0.07)subscriptùëöùëãplus-or-minus3.870.07m_{X}=(3.87\pm 0.07) GeV, as shown in Table 2.

We see that, in both cases, a good agreement with the experimental mass was obtained. Up to now there are many QCDSR calculations[28] of the the mass of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) considering different currents and in all cases good agreement with the experimental mass is found. Even with a mixed charmonium-molecular current the value obtained for the mass does not change significantly [44]. These calculations only confirm the result presented in Ref.¬†[\refciteNarison:2010pd] that shows that the calculation of the mass of a given state, in the QCDSR approach, is very insensitive to the choice of the current. However, this may not be the case for the decay width[45].

3.2 Decay width

The first QCDSR calculation of the width of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) was done in Ref.¬†[\refcitewidth]. In particular, in Ref.¬†[\refcitewidth] the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) was considered as a tetraquark state described by the current in Eq.¬†(15) and a very large decay width was obtained: Œì‚Äã(X‚ÜíJ/œà‚ÄãœÅ‚ÜíJ/œà‚ÄãœÄ+‚ÄãœÄ‚àí)=(50¬±15)‚ÄãMeVŒì‚ÜíùëãùêΩùúìùúå‚ÜíùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãsuperscriptùúãplus-or-minus5015MeV\Gamma(X\to J/\psi\rho\to J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-})=(50\pm 15)~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}. A similar width was obtained in Ref.¬†[\refcitex24] with a molecular current such as the one in Eq.¬†(16). Indeed, large partial decay widths are expected when the coupling constant is obtained from QCDSR, in the case of multiquark states, when the initial state contains the same number of valence quarks as the number of valence quarks in the final state. An example is the case of the light scalars œÉùúé\sigma and Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa studied in Ref.¬†[\refcitesca], which widths are of the order of 400 MeV. In the case of the X‚ÜíJ/œà‚ÄãœÅ‚ÜíùëãùêΩùúìùúåX\to J/\psi\rho decay, the generic decay diagram in terms of quarks has two ‚Äúpetals‚Äù, one associated with the J/œàùêΩùúìJ/\psi and the other with the œÅùúå\rho.

Among the possible diagrams, there are two distinct subsets. Diagrams with no gluon exchange between the petals, as the one shown in Fig.¬†1(a), and therefore, no color exchange between the two final mesons in the decay. If there is no color exchange, the final state containing two color singlets was already present in the initial state. In this case the tetraquark had a component similar to a J/œà‚àíœÅùêΩùúìùúåJ/\psi-\rho molecule. The other subset of diagrams is the one where there is a gluon exchange between the petals, as the one shown in Fig.¬†1(b). This type of diagram represents the case where the XùëãX is a genuine four-quark state with a complicated color structure. These diagrams are called color-conected (CC). Considering only the CC diagrams in the calculation, the decay width obtained in Ref.¬†[\refcitewidth] was:

ŒìC‚ÄãC‚Äã(X‚ÜíJ/œà‚ÄãœÅ‚ÜíJ‚Äãœà‚ÄãœÄ+‚ÄãœÄ‚àí)=(0.7¬±0.2)‚ÄãMeV,subscriptŒìùê∂ùê∂‚ÜíùëãùêΩùúìùúå‚ÜíùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãsuperscriptùúãplus-or-minus0.70.2MeV\Gamma_{CC}(X\to J/\psi~{}\rho\to J\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-})=(0.7\pm 0.2)~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}, (17)

in a very good agreement with the experimental upper limit.

This procedure may appear somewhat unjustified. However, if the initial state has a non-trivial color structure only CC diagrams should contribute to the calculation. Unfortunately, although the initial tetraquark current has a non-trivial color structure, it can be rewritten as a sum of molecular type currents with trivial color configuration through a Fierz transformation. This is the reason why the diagrams without gluon exchange between the two ‚Äúpetals‚Äù survive in the QCDSR calculation. Therefore, the approach of considering only CC diagrams can be considered as a form of simulating a real tetraquark state with non-trivial color structure.

Other possible approach to reduce the large widht is to consider the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) as a mixture between a c‚Äãc¬Øùëê¬Øùëêc\bar{c} current and a molecular current, as done in Ref.¬†[\refcitex24]:

JŒº‚Äã(x)=sin‚Å°(Œ±)‚ÄãjŒºm‚Äão‚Äãl‚Äã(x)+cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚ÄãjŒº2‚Äã(x),subscriptùêΩùúáùë•ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëóùëöùëúùëôùúáùë•ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëó2ùúáùë•J_{\mu}(x)=\sin(\alpha)j^{mol}_{\mu}(x)+\cos(\alpha)j^{2}_{\mu}(x), (18)

with jŒºm‚Äão‚Äãl‚Äã(x)subscriptsuperscriptùëóùëöùëúùëôùúáùë•j^{mol}_{\mu}(x) given in Eq.¬†(16) and

jŒº2‚Äã(x)=16‚Äã2‚Äã‚ü®q¬Ø‚Äãq‚ü©‚Äã[c¬Øa‚Äã(x)‚ÄãŒ≥Œº‚ÄãŒ≥5‚Äãca‚Äã(x)].subscriptsuperscriptùëó2ùúáùë•162delimited-‚ü®‚ü©¬Øùëûùëûdelimited-[]subscript¬Øùëêùëéùë•subscriptùõæùúásubscriptùõæ5subscriptùëêùëéùë•j^{2}_{\mu}(x)={1\over 6\sqrt{2}}\langle\bar{q}q\rangle[\bar{c}_{a}(x)\gamma_{\mu}\gamma_{5}c_{a}(x)]. (19)

The necessity of mixing a c‚Äãc¬Øùëê¬Øùëêc\bar{c} component with the D0‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àó0superscriptùê∑0superscript¬Øùê∑absent0D^{0}\bar{D}^{*0} molecule was already pointed out in some works [48, 49, 50, 51]. In particular, in Ref.¬†[\refcitegrinstein], a simulation of the production of a bound D0‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àó0superscriptùê∑0superscript¬Øùê∑absent0D^{0}\bar{D}^{*0} state with binding energy as small as 0.25 MeV, obtained a cross section of about two orders of magnitude smaller than the prompt production cross section of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) observed by the CDF Collaboration. The authors of Ref.¬†[\refcitegrinstein] concluded that SùëÜS-wave resonant scattering is unlikely to allow the formation of a loosely bound D0‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àó0superscriptùê∑0superscript¬Øùê∑absent0D^{0}\bar{D}^{*0} molecule in high energy hadron collision.

As discussed above, there is no problem in reproducing the experimental mass of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872), using the current in Eq.¬†(18), for a wide range of the mixture angle Œ±ùõº\alpha. However, the value of the X‚ÄãJ/œà‚ÄãœÅùëãùêΩùúìùúåXJ/\psi\rho coupling constant and, therefore, the value of the X‚ÜíJ/œà‚Äã(n‚ÄãœÄ)‚ÜíùëãùêΩùúìùëõùúãX\to J/\psi~{}(n\pi) decay width, is strongly dependent on this angle. It was shown in Ref.¬†[\refcitex24] that for a mixing angle Œ±=90¬±40ùõºplus-or-minussuperscript90superscript40\alpha=9^{0}\pm 4^{0}, it is possible to describe the experimental mass of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) with a decay width Œì‚Äã(X‚ÜíJ/œà‚Äã(n‚ÄãœÄ))=(9.3¬±6.9)‚ÄãMeVŒì‚ÜíùëãùêΩùúìùëõùúãplus-or-minus9.36.9MeV\Gamma(X\to J/\psi~{}(n\pi))=(9.3\pm 6.9)~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}, which is compatible with the experimental upper limit. Therefore, in a QCDSR calculation, the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) can be well described basically by a c‚Äãc¬Øùëê¬Øùëêc\bar{c} current with a small, but fundamental, admixture of molecular (D‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àóùê∑superscript¬Øùê∑D\bar{D}^{*}) or tetraquark ([c‚Äãq]‚Äã[c¬Ø‚Äãq¬Ø]delimited-[]ùëêùëûdelimited-[]¬Øùëê¬Øùëû[cq][\bar{c}\bar{q}]) currents.

4 Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430)

This resonance was found by Belle Collaboration in the channel B+‚ÜíK‚Äãœà‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÄ+‚Üísuperscriptùêµùêæsuperscriptùúì‚Ä≤superscriptùúãB^{+}\to K\psi^{\prime}\pi^{+} and it was the first charged charmonium state observed, with mass M=(4433‚àí12‚àí13+15+19)ùëÄsubscriptsuperscript443315191213M=(4433^{+15+19}_{-12-13}) MeV and width Œì=(109‚àí43‚àí56+86+74¬±18¬±30)Œìplus-or-minussubscriptsuperscript109867443561830\Gamma=(109^{+86+74}_{-43-56}\pm 18\pm 30) MeV [7]. Curiously, there is no signal of this resonance in the J/œà‚ÄãœÄ+ùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãJ/\psi\pi^{+} channel. Since the minimal quark content of this state is c‚Äãc¬Ø‚Äãu‚Äãd¬Øùëê¬Øùëêùë¢¬Øùëëc\bar{c}u\bar{d} this can only be achieved in a multiquark configuration.

The Babar Collaboration searched the Z‚àí‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{-}(4430) in the four decay modes B+‚ÜíKS0‚Äãœà‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÄ‚àí‚Üísuperscriptùêµsubscriptsuperscriptùêæ0ùëÜsuperscriptùúì‚Ä≤superscriptùúãB^{+}\to K^{0}_{S}\psi^{\prime}\pi^{-}, B+‚ÜíKS0‚ÄãJ/œà‚ÄãœÄ‚àí‚Üísuperscriptùêµsubscriptsuperscriptùêæ0ùëÜùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãB^{+}\to K^{0}_{S}J/\psi\pi^{-}, B+‚ÜíK+‚Äãœà‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÄ0‚Üísuperscriptùêµsuperscriptùêæsuperscriptùúì‚Ä≤superscriptùúã0B^{+}\to K^{+}\psi^{\prime}\pi^{0} and B+‚ÜíK+‚ÄãJ/œà‚ÄãœÄ0‚ÜísuperscriptùêµsuperscriptùêæùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúã0B^{+}\to K^{+}J/\psi\pi^{0}. No significant evidence of a signal peak was found in any of the processes investigated [8].

Since the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) mass is close to the D‚àó‚ÄãD1superscriptùê∑subscriptùê∑1D^{*}D_{1} threshold, it was suggested that it could be an S-wave threshold effect or a D‚àó‚ÄãD1superscriptùê∑subscriptùê∑1D^{*}D_{1} molecular state. Considering the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) as a weakly bound SùëÜS-wave D‚àó‚ÄãD1superscriptùê∑subscriptùê∑1D^{*}D_{1} molecular state, its quantum numbers may be JP=0‚àí,1‚àí,2‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript0superscript1superscript2J^{P}=0^{-},~{}1^{-},~{}2^{-}. The 2‚àísuperscript22^{-} assignment is probably suppressed in the B+‚ÜíZ+‚ÄãK‚ÜísuperscriptùêµsuperscriptùëçùêæB^{+}\to Z^{+}K decay beacuse of the small phase space. Other possible interpretations are a tetraquark state, a cusp in the D‚àó‚ÄãD1superscriptùê∑subscriptùê∑1D^{*}D_{1} channel, a baryonium state, a radially excited c‚Äãs¬Øùëê¬Øùë†c\bar{s} state and a hadrocharmonium state [28].

There are QCDSR calculations for the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) assuming that the state could have JP=0‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{-} or JP=1‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} quantum numbers [53, 54]. In the first case the obtained masses were mm‚Äão‚Äãl‚Äã(0‚àí)=(4.40¬±0.10)subscriptùëöùëöùëúùëôsuperscript0plus-or-minus4.400.10m_{mol}(0^{-})=(4.40\pm 0.10) GeV for a D‚àó‚ÄãD1superscriptùê∑subscriptùê∑1D^{*}D_{1} molecular current [53] and md‚Äãi‚Äã(0‚àí)=(4.52¬±0.09)subscriptùëöùëëùëñsuperscript0plus-or-minus4.520.09m_{di}(0^{-})=(4.52\pm 0.09) GeV for a diquark-antidiquark current [54]. In the second assignment and for a diquark-antidiquark current the obtained mass was md‚Äãi‚Äã(1‚àí)=(4.84¬±0.14)subscriptùëöùëëùëñsuperscript1plus-or-minus4.840.14m_{di}(1^{-})=(4.84\pm 0.14) GeV [54]. These numbers are displayed in Table 2.

From these results the preliminary conclusion, at the time, was that the assignment JP=1‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} was disfavored and that the configuration JP=0‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{-}, in both molecular and tetraquark states, would lead to a mass which is in agreement with the data. However, a recent reanalysis of the Belle data revealed that the favored quantum numbers are JP=1+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} [9]. It is important to mention that soon after the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) was first observed, Maiani et al. have suggested that the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) could be the first radial excitation of a charged partner of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872), and therefore, would have JP=1+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} quantum numbers [55]. The existence of a charged partner of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) was first proposed in Ref.¬†[\refcitemaiani].

Clearly, in view of the recent experimental reanalysis, if the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) really exist, it could be a œà‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÄ+superscriptùúì‚Ä≤superscriptùúã\psi^{\prime}\pi^{+} resonance or a tetraquark excitation, which invalidates a QCDSR calculation.

5 Z1+‚Äã(4050)subscriptsuperscriptùëç14050Z^{+}_{1}(4050) and Z2+‚Äã(4250)subscriptsuperscriptùëç24250Z^{+}_{2}(4250)

After the observation of the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) other B¬Ø0‚ÜíK‚àí‚ÄãœÄ+‚Äã(c‚Äãc¬Ø)‚Üísuperscript¬Øùêµ0superscriptùêæsuperscriptùúãùëê¬Øùëê\bar{B}^{0}\to K^{-}\pi^{+}(c\bar{c}) decays were carefully investigated. Two resonance-like structures, called Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) and Z2+‚Äã(4250)superscriptsubscriptùëç24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250), were observed by the Belle Collaboration in the exclusive process B¬Ø0‚ÜíK‚àí‚ÄãœÄ+‚Äãœác‚Äã1‚Üísuperscript¬Øùêµ0superscriptùêæsuperscriptùúãsubscriptùúíùëê1\bar{B}^{0}\to K^{-}\pi^{+}\chi_{c1}, in the œÄ+‚Äãœác‚Äã1superscriptùúãsubscriptùúíùëê1\pi^{+}\chi_{c1} mass distribution [10]. The significance of each of the œÄ+‚Äãœác‚Äã1superscriptùúãsubscriptùúíùëê1\pi^{+}\chi_{c1} structures exceeds 5 œÉùúé\sigma and, since they were observed in the œÄ+‚Äãœác‚Äã1superscriptùúãsubscriptùúíùëê1\pi^{+}\chi_{c1} channel, they must have the quantum numbers IG=1‚àísuperscriptùêºùê∫superscript1I^{G}=1^{-}. Also in this case the BaBar colaboration did not confirm these observations [11]. When fitted with two Breit-Wigner resonance amplitudes, the resonance parameters are m1=(4051¬±14‚àí41+20)subscriptùëö1plus-or-minus4051subscriptsuperscript142041m_{1}=(4051\pm 14^{+20}_{-41}) MeV, Œì1=(82‚àí17‚àí22+21+47)subscriptŒì1subscriptsuperscript8221471722\Gamma_{1}=(82^{+21+47}_{-17-22}) MeV, m2=(4248‚àí29‚àí35+44+180)subscriptùëö2subscriptsuperscript4248441802935m_{2}=(4248^{+44+180}_{-29-35}) MeV and Œì2=(177‚àí39‚àí61+54+316)subscriptŒì2subscriptsuperscript177543163961\Gamma_{2}=(177^{+54+316}_{-39-61}) MeV.

Since the masses of the Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) and Z2+‚Äã(4250)superscriptsubscriptùëç24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) are close to the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø‚Äã(4020)superscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑4020D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}(4020) and D1‚ÄãD¬Ø‚Äã(4085)subscriptùê∑1¬Øùê∑4085D_{1}\bar{D}(4085) thresholds, it is natural to interpret these states as molecular states or threshold effects. However calculations using meson exchange models do not agree with each other. In Ref.¬†[\refcitelium], a strong attraction in the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} with JP=0+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{+} was found, while in Ref.¬†[\refciteding] the interpretation of Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) as a D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} molecule was not favored. In any case, it is very difficult to understand a bound molecular state which mass is above the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} threshold. In Ref.¬†[\refciteding2] the interpretation of Z2+‚Äã(4250)superscriptsubscriptùëç24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) as a D1‚ÄãD¬Øsubscriptùê∑1¬Øùê∑D_{1}\bar{D} or D0‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsubscriptùê∑0¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D_{0}\bar{D^{*}} molecule was disfavored.

Soon after the observation of these states, QCDSR were used[59] to study the D‚àó‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àósuperscriptùê∑superscript¬Øùê∑D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} and D1‚ÄãD¬Øsubscriptùê∑1¬Øùê∑D_{1}\bar{D} molecular states with IG‚ÄãJP=1‚àí‚Äã0+superscriptùêºùê∫superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1superscript0I^{G}J^{P}=1^{-}0^{+} and 1‚àí‚Äã1‚àísuperscript1superscript11^{-}1^{-} respectively. The currents used in both cases were of the type of Eq.¬†(16). As shown in Table 2, for the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} system the obtained mass was mD‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó=(4.15¬±0.12)subscriptùëösuperscriptùê∑superscriptùê∑plus-or-minus4.150.12m_{D^{*}D^{*}}=(4.15\pm 0.12) GeV. Since the central value of the mass is around 130 MeV above the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó‚Äã(4020)superscriptùê∑superscriptùê∑4020D^{*}D^{*}(4020) threshold, we can conclude that there are repulsive interactions between the two D‚àósuperscriptùê∑D^{*} mesons. Therefore, it is not clear whether this structure is a resonance or not. For the D1‚ÄãD¬Øsubscriptùê∑1¬Øùê∑D_{1}\bar{D} system the obtained mass was mD1‚ÄãD=(4.19¬±0.22)subscriptùëösubscriptùê∑1ùê∑plus-or-minus4.190.22m_{D_{1}D}=(4.19\pm 0.22) GeV. Here, in contrast to the previous case, the central value is around 100 MeV below the D1‚ÄãD‚Äã(4285)subscriptùê∑1ùê∑4285D_{1}D(4285) threshold, and, considering the errors, consistent with the mass of the Z2+‚Äã(4250)superscriptsubscriptùëç24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) resonance structure. Therefore, in this case, there seems to be an atractive interaction between the mesons D1subscriptùê∑1D_{1} and Dùê∑D and the molecular interpretation of this state seems more justified.

QCD sum rules estimate always contain some uncertainties. In the study of the masses of the charged ZùëçZ states, part of the theoretical uncertainty comes from the width of the state. In most cases, the widht is neglected. In the present case, when the width is included in the phenomenological side of the sum rule, the mass of the corresponding state increases[60]. It becomes then possible to obtain a mass mD1‚ÄãD=4.25‚ÄãGeVsubscriptùëösubscriptùê∑1ùê∑4.25GeVm_{D_{1}D}=4.25~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{GeV} with a width 40‚â§Œì‚â§60‚ÄãMeV40Œì60MeV40\leq\Gamma\leq 60~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}. Following the same trend, the mass of the D‚àó‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àósuperscriptùê∑superscript¬Øùê∑D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} molecule will be far from the Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) mass. In view of these facts, the authors of Ref.¬†[\refciteleeniel] concluded that it is possible to describe the Z2+‚Äã(4250)superscriptsubscriptùëç24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) as a D1‚ÄãD¬Øsubscriptùê∑1¬Øùê∑D_{1}\bar{D} molecular state with IG‚ÄãJP=1‚àí‚Äã1‚àísuperscriptùêºùê∫superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1superscript1I^{G}J^{P}=1^{-}1^{-} quantum numbers. They also concluded that the D‚àó‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àósuperscriptùê∑superscript¬Øùê∑D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} state is probably a virtual state that is not related with the Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) resonance-like structure. Since the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àósuperscriptùê∑superscriptùê∑D^{*}D^{*} threshold (4020)4020(4020) is so close to the Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) mass and the Œ∑c‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(31‚ÄãS0)subscriptsuperscriptùúÇ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëêsuperscript31subscriptùëÜ0\eta^{\prime\prime}_{c}(3^{1}S_{0}) mass is predicted to be around 4050 MeV, the Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) is probably only a threshold effect.

6 Zc+‚Äã(3900)subscriptsuperscriptùëçùëê3900Z^{+}_{c}(3900)

After the non-confirmed observations of Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430), Z1+‚Äã(4050)subscriptsuperscriptùëç14050Z^{+}_{1}(4050) and Z2+‚Äã(4250)subscriptsuperscriptùëç24250Z^{+}_{2}(4250), only seen by Belle, the BESIII and Belle collaborations reported the observation of a charged charmonium-like structure in the M‚Äã(œÄ¬±‚ÄãJ/œà)ùëÄsuperscriptùúãplus-or-minusùêΩùúìM(\pi^{\pm}J/\psi) mass spectrum of the Y‚Äã(4260)‚ÜíJ/œà‚ÄãœÄ+‚ÄãœÄ‚àí‚Üíùëå4260ùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãsuperscriptùúãY(4260)\to J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-} decay channel [12, 13]. The existence of this structure, called Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900), was promptly confirmed by the the authors of Ref.¬†[\refciteXiao:2013iha] using CLEO-c data.

In most of the theoretical calculations it is relatively easy to reproduce the masses of the states. In the case of the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900), assuming S‚ÄãU‚Äã(2)ùëÜùëà2SU(2) symmetry, the mass obtained in QCDSR for the ZcsubscriptùëçùëêZ_{c} is exactly the same one obtained for the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872). As discussed in Sec. 3.2, it is, however, much more difficult to reproduce their measured decay widths. The Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900) decay width represents a challenge to theorists. While its mass is very close to the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) mass, which may be considered its isosinglet partner, it has a much larger decay width. Indeed, while the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900) decay width is in the range 40‚àí50405040-50 MeV, the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) width is smaller than 1.21.21.2 MeV.

This difference can be attributed to the fact that the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) may contain a significant |c‚Äãc¬Ø‚ü©ketùëê¬Øùëê|c\bar{c}\rangle component[44], which is absent in the Zc‚Äã(3990)subscriptùëçùëê3990Z_{c}(3990). As pointed out in Ref.¬†[\refcitezhao], this would also explain why the ZcsubscriptùëçùëêZ_{c} has not been observed in BùêµB decays.

According to the experimental observations, the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900) decays into J/œà‚ÄãœÄ+ùêΩùúìsuperscriptùúãJ/\psi\,\pi^{+} with a relatively large decay width. This is unexpected for a D‚àó‚àíD¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øùê∑D^{*}-\bar{D} molecular state, in which the distance between the D‚àósuperscriptùê∑D^{*} and the D¬Ø¬Øùê∑\bar{D} is large. This decay must involve the exchange of a charmed meson, which is a short range process and hence unlikely to occur in large systems. In Ref.¬†[\refcitenamit] it was shown that, in order to reproduce the measured width, the effective radius must be ‚ü®re‚Äãf‚Äãf‚ü©‚âÉ0.4similar-to-or-equalsdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùëüùëíùëìùëì0.4\langle r_{eff}\rangle\simeq 0.4 fm. This size scale is small and pushes the molecular picture to its limit of validity. In another work[63], the new state was treated as a charged D‚àó‚àíD¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øùê∑D^{*}-\bar{D} molecule and the authors explored its electromagnetic structure, arriving at the conclusion that its charge radius is of the order of ‚ü®r2‚ü©‚âÉ0.11similar-to-or-equalsdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©superscriptùëü20.11\langle r^{2}\rangle\simeq 0.11 fm2. Taking this radius as a measure of the spatial size of the state, we conclude that it is more compact than a J/œàùêΩùúìJ/\psi, for which ‚ü®r2‚ü©‚âÉ0.16similar-to-or-equalsdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©superscriptùëü20.16\langle r^{2}\rangle\simeq 0.16 fm2. In Ref.¬†[\refciteDias:2013xfa] the combined results of Refs.¬†[\refcitenamit] and [\refcitehammer] were taken as an indication that the ZcsubscriptùëçùëêZ_{c} is a compact object, which may be better understood as a quark cluster, such as a tetraquark. Moreover, the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900) was interpreted as the isospin 1 partner of the X‚Äã(3278)ùëã3278X(3278), as the charged state predicted in Ref.¬†[\refcitemaiani]. Therefore, the quantum numbers for the neutral state in the isospin multiplet were assumed to be IG‚Äã(JP‚ÄãC)=1+‚Äã(1+‚àí)superscriptùêºùê∫superscriptùêΩùëÉùê∂superscript1superscript1absentI^{G}(J^{PC})=1^{+}(1^{+-}). The interpolating field for Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) used in Ref.¬†[\refciteDias:2013xfa] is given by Eq.¬†(15) with the plus signal changed by a minus signal. In all cases only color-connected diagrams were considered, since the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900) is expected to be a genuine tetraquark state with a non-trivial color structure. 7 Zc+‚Äã(4025)subscriptsuperscriptùëçùëê4025Z^{+}_{c}(4025), Zc+‚Äã(4020)subscriptsuperscriptùëçùëê4020Z^{+}_{c}(4020) and Zc+‚Äã(3885)subscriptsuperscriptùëçùëê3885Z^{+}_{c}(3885) : are they real ?

Very recently the BESIII Collaboration reported the observation of other three charges states: Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) [15], Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) [16] and Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) [17].

In the BESIII set-up a reaction e+‚Äãe‚àí‚Üí(D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)¬±‚ÄãœÄ‚àì‚Üísuperscriptùëísuperscriptùëí‚àísuperscriptsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑plus-or-minussuperscriptùúãminus-or-pluse^{+}e^{‚àí}\rightarrow(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm}\pi^{\mp} was performed at s=4.26ùë†4.26\sqrt{s}=4.26 GeV and a peak was seen in the (D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)¬±superscriptsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑plus-or-minus(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm} invariant mass distribution just about 101010 MeV above the threshold. The peak was identified as a new particle, the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) [15]. The authors assume in the paper that the (D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)¬±superscriptsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑plus-or-minus(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm} pair is created in a S-wave and then the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) must have JP=1+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} to match, together with the pion, the quantum numbers JP=1‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} of the virtual photon from the e+‚Äãe‚àísuperscriptùëísuperscriptùëíe^{+}e^{-} pair. However, they also state that the experiment does not exclude other spin-parity assignments. Since the (D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)¬±superscriptsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑plus-or-minus(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm} has charge, the isospin must be I = 1.

In parallel with the experimental works many theoretical papers were devoted to understand these new states. In Ref.¬†[\refcitehidalgo], Heavy Quark Spin Symmetry (HQSS) was used to make predictions for states containing one Dùê∑D or D‚àósuperscriptùê∑D^{*} and one D¬Ø¬Øùê∑\bar{D} or D‚àó¬Ø¬Øsuperscriptùê∑\bar{D^{*}}. Assuming the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) to be D‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D\bar{D^{*}} molecule, the authors found a series of new hadronic molecules, including the Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) and the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025). They would correspond to bound states (with uncertainties of about 505050 MeV in the binding) of D‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D\bar{D^{*}} and D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} respectively, with quantum numbers I‚Äã(JP)=1‚Äã(1+)ùêºsuperscriptùêΩùëÉ1superscript1I(J^{P})=1(1^{+}). Remarkably, even with uncertainties, these states always appear in the bound region. In Refs.¬†[\refcitechen,cui], using QCD sum rules and assuming a structure of D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}, the authors obtained a possible I‚Äã(JP)=1‚Äã(1+)ùêºsuperscriptùêΩùëÉ1superscript1I(J^{P})=1(1^{+}) state compatible with the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) albeit with around 250250250 MeV uncertainty in the energy. Recently [69], a study of the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} system has also been done within QCD sum rules, projecting the correlation function on spin-parity 0+superscript00^{+}, 1+superscript11^{+} and 2+superscript22^{+}. In the three cases a state with mass 3950¬±100plus-or-minus39501003950\pm 100 MeV was found. The central value of the mass of these states is more in line with the results of Refs.¬†[\refciteraquel,oset], although with the error bar, they could as well be related to a resonance. In Ref.¬†[\refcitesunzhu] the new ZcsubscriptùëçùëêZ_{c} states were investigated from a different perspective and, using pion exchange, a D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} state with I‚Äã(JP)=1‚Äã(1+)ùêºsuperscriptùêΩùëÉ1superscript1I(J^{P})=1(1^{+}) compatible with the Zc‚Äã(4025)subscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}(4025) was obtained. One should note that the input used in this latter work is quite different from the one in Ref.¬†[\refcitehidalgo] since in HQSS the pion exchange is subdominant. Finally, in Ref.¬†[\refciteqtang], using a tetraquark structure and QCDSR, a state with I‚Äã(JP)=1‚Äã(2+)ùêºsuperscriptùêΩùëÉ1superscript2I(J^{P})=1(2^{+}) compatible with Zc‚Äã(4025)subscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}(4025) was obtained, once again with a large error in the energy of 190190190 MeV. In a different analysis, in Ref.¬†[\refcitematsuki] a pion and the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} state are produced from the X‚Äã(4260)ùëã4260X(4260) and the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} state is left to interact, while the pion remains a spectator (initial single-pion emission mechanism). Although it is not mentioned whether the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} interaction produces a resonance with certain quantum numbers, the authors show that the mechanism can produce some enhancement in the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} invariant mass distribution just above threshold.

Bumps close to the threshold of a pair of particles should be treated with caution. Sometimes they are identified as new particles, but they can also be a reflection of a resonance below threshold. In a similar reaction, e+‚Äãe‚àí‚ÜíJ/œà‚Äã(D‚ÄãD¬Ø)‚ÜísuperscriptùëísuperscriptùëíùêΩùúìùê∑¬Øùê∑e^{+}e^{-}\rightarrow J/\psi(D\bar{D}), the Belle Collaboration reported [75] a bump close to the threshold in the (D‚ÄãD¬Ø)ùê∑¬Øùê∑(D\bar{D}) invariant mass distribution, which was tentatively interpreted as a new resonance. However, in Ref.¬†[\refcitegamm08] it was shown that the bump was better interpreted in terms of a (D‚ÄãD¬Ø)ùê∑¬Øùê∑(D\bar{D}) molecular state, below the (D‚ÄãD¬Ø)ùê∑¬Øùê∑(D\bar{D}) threshold (the so called X‚Äã(3700)ùëã3700X(3700)). Similarly, in Ref.¬†[\refcitetokhenno13] the œï‚Äãœâitalic-œïùúî\phi\,\omega threshold peak measured [78] in the J/œà‚ÜíŒ≥‚Äãœï‚Äãœâ‚ÜíùêΩùúìùõæitalic-œïùúîJ/\psi\rightarrow\gamma\phi\omega reaction was better interpreted as a signal of the f0‚Äã(1710)subscriptùëì01710f_{0}(1710) resonance, below the œï‚Äãœâitalic-œïùúî\phi\,\omega threshold, which couples strongly to œï‚Äãœâitalic-œïùúî\phi\,\omega. Further examples of this phenomenon may be found in Ref.¬†[\refcitetokhenno14]. In that work the theory of D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} interactions is reviewed and it is pointed out that a (D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)superscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}) state with a mass above the threshold is very difficult to support. In particular, in Ref.¬†[\refciteoset] it was found that there is only one bound state of (D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)superscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}) in IG=1‚àísuperscriptùêºùê∫superscript1I^{G}=1^{-}, with quantum numbers JP‚ÄãC=2++superscriptùêΩùëÉùê∂superscript2absentJ^{PC}=2^{++} with a mass around 399039903990 MeV and a width of about 100100100 MeV. Both mass and width are compatible with the reanalysis of data carried out in Ref.¬†[\refcitetokhenno14]. Therefore, we can conclude that such JP=2+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript2J^{P}=2^{+} D‚àó‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àósuperscriptùê∑superscript¬Øùê∑D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} bound state provides a natural explanation for the state observed in [15].

An argument against the existence of a new resonance above the threshold is the fact that if the state were a JP=1+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} produced in S-wave, as assumed in the experimental work, it would easily decay into J/œà‚ÄãœÄùêΩùúìùúãJ/\psi\pi exchanging a Dùê∑D meson in the t-channel. This is also the decay channel of the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900), which would then have the same quantum numbers as the state claimed in Ref.¬†[\refciteAblikim:2013emm]. However, while a peak is clearly seen in the J/œà‚ÄãœÄùêΩùúìùúãJ/\psi\pi invariant mass distribution in the case of the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900), no trace of a peak is seen around 402540254025 MeV in spite of using the same reaction and the same e+‚Äãe‚àísuperscriptùëísuperscriptùëíe^{+}e^{-} energy.

Less than a month after the observation of the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025), the BESIII Collaboration reported the observation of the Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020), a structure observed in the hc‚ÄãœÄ¬±subscript‚Ñéùëêsuperscriptùúãplus-or-minush_{c}\pi^{\pm} mass spectrum [16] . The difference between the parameters of this structure and the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025), observed in the D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} final state, is within 1.5‚ÄãœÉ1.5ùúé1.5\,\sigma and it is not clear whether they are the same state or not. The authors do not find a significant signal for Zc+‚Äã(3900)‚Üíhc‚ÄãœÄ¬±‚Üísuperscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900subscript‚Ñéùëêsuperscriptùúãplus-or-minusZ_{c}^{+}(3900)\rightarrow h_{c}\pi^{\pm}.

Since the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and the Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) have almost the same mass and their quantum numbers were not yet accurately determined, we might think that they are, in fact, the same particle. Looking only at the most natural quantum numbers of the final states, the S-wave D‚àó‚ÄãD‚àó¬Øsuperscriptùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} states have the quantum numbers JP=0+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{+}, 1+superscript11^{+} and 2+superscript22^{+}, while the S-wave hc‚ÄãœÄ¬±subscript‚Ñéùëêsuperscriptùúãplus-or-minush_{c}\pi^{\pm} states have the quantum numbers JP=1‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-}. Therefore the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) would be different particles. However, it is also possible to have a P-wave hc‚ÄãœÄ¬±subscript‚Ñéùëêsuperscriptùúãplus-or-minush_{c}\pi^{\pm} system with quantum numbers JP=0+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{+} 1+superscript11^{+} and 2+superscript22^{+}. In this case the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and the Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) could be the same particle.

In the analysis presented in Ref.¬†[\refcitegang1], the author concluded that QCDSR do not support the picture of Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) as diquark-antidiquark vector tetraquark states with JP=1‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-}. A short time later, in Ref.¬†[\refcitegang2] the author concluded that, for these two states (treated as a single state), the QCDSR analysis supports the assignements JP=1+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} and JP=2+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript2J^{P}=2^{+} in a diquark-antidiquark configuration.

Shortly after the observation of the Zc+‚Äã(4020)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) the same collaboration reported the measurement of the Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885), a charged structure observed in the (D‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)¬±limit-fromùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑plus-or-minus(D\bar{D^{*}})\pm invariant mass distribution [17]. The mass and width of this structure are 2‚ÄãœÉ2ùúé2\sigma and 1‚ÄãœÉ1ùúé1\sigma, respectively, below those of the Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900). The angular distribution of the œÄ‚ÄãZc‚Äã(3885)ùúãsubscriptùëçùëê3885\pi Z_{c}(3885) system favors the JP=1+superscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} assignment and disfavors JP=1‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} or JP=0‚àísuperscriptùêΩùëÉsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{-}. Regarding the fact that this state could be the Zc‚Äã(3900)subscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}(3900), saw in a different decay channel, the only comment from the experimental side is that if the Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) and Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) are the same state, then the ratio

Œì‚Äã(Zc‚Äã(3885)‚ÜíD‚ÄãD¬Ø‚àó)Œì‚Äã(Zc‚Äã(3900)‚ÜíœÄ‚ÄãJ/œà)=6.2¬±1.1¬±2.7Œì‚Üísubscriptùëçùëê3885ùê∑superscript¬Øùê∑Œì‚Üísubscriptùëçùëê3900ùúãùêΩùúìplus-or-minus6.21.12.7{\Gamma(Z_{c}(3885)\to D\bar{D}^{*})\over\Gamma(Z_{c}(3900)\to\pi J/\psi)}=6.2\pm 1.1\pm 2.7 (21)

is determined [17].

Comparing the results in Eqs.¬†(20) and (21) we can conclude that, if the ratio in Eq.¬†(21) is confirmed, the states Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) and Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) are not the same state.

Here again, as in the case of the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) discussed above, it is possible that the Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885)) is not a real state but a manifestation of a resonance with a mass below the (D‚ÄãD‚àó¬Ø)ùê∑¬Øsuperscriptùê∑(D\bar{D^{*}}) threshold. This point remains to be clarified.

8 Towards a new spectroscopy

The proliferation of new charmonium states motivates attempts to group them into families. One possible way to organize some of the charmonium and bottomonium new states was suggested in Ref.¬†[\refciteNavarra:2011xa] and it is summarized in Fig. 2. In this figure we present the charm and bottom spectra in the mass region of interest. On the left (right) we show the charm (bottom) states with their mass differences in MeV. The comparison between the two left lines with the two lines on the right emphasizes the similarity between the spectra. In the bottom of the second column we have the newly found Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900).

The existence of a charged partner of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) was first proposed in Ref.¬†[\refcitemaiani]. A few years later[55] the same group proposed that the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430), observed by BELLE[7], would be the first radial excitation of the charged partner of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872). This suggestion was supported by the fact that the mass difference corresponding to a radial excitation in the charmonium sector is given by MŒ®‚Äã(2‚ÄãS)‚àíMŒ®‚Äã(1‚ÄãS)‚àº590similar-tosubscriptùëÄŒ®2ùëÜsubscriptùëÄŒ®1ùëÜ590M_{\Psi(2S)}-M_{\Psi(1S)}\sim 590 MeV. This number is close to the mass difference MZ+‚Äã(4430)‚àíMX+‚Äã(3872)‚àº560similar-tosubscriptùëÄsuperscriptùëç4430subscriptùëÄsuperscriptùëã3872560M_{Z^{+}(4430)}-M_{X^{+}(3872)}\sim 560 MeV. A similar connection between Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) and Zc+‚Äã(3900)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) was found in the hadro-charmonium approach[83], where the former is essentially a Œ®‚Ä≤superscriptŒ®‚Ä≤\Psi^{\prime} embedded in light mesonic matter and the latter a J/œàùêΩùúìJ/\psi also embedded in light mesonic matter. In Ref.¬†[\refciteNavarra:2011xa] this reasoning was extended to the bottom sector and it was conjectured that the Zb+‚Äã(10610)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëè10610Z_{b}^{+}(10610), observed by the BELLE collaboration in Ref.¬†[\refcitebellezb], might be a radial excitation of an yet unmeasured Xb+superscriptsubscriptùëãùëèX_{b}^{+}, predicted in Ref.¬†[\refcitex3872]. The observation of Zc+‚Äã(3990)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3990Z_{c}^{+}(3990) gives support to this conjecture and should motivate new experimental searches of this bottom charged state and its neutral partner, the only missing states in the diagram.

9 Conclusion

The most important message from the experimental program carried out at Belle and BESIII is that definitely there is something really new happening in the charmonium spectroscopy. This started in 2003 with the measurement of the X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872), which has a very robust experimental signature and has been neasured by many different groups. The X‚Äã(3872)ùëã3872X(3872) is electrically neutral and hence its multiquark nature was not clear from the beginning. Five years later, in 2008, the observation of Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430), Z1+‚Äã(4050)superscriptsubscriptùëç14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) and Z2+‚Äã(4250)superscriptsubscriptùëç24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) would have been the proof of the existence of multiquark configurations in the charmonium sector. However the non-confirmation of these measurements rendered this claim weak. Another five years later, in 2013, the confirmation of the observation of the Z+‚Äã(4430)superscriptùëç4430Z^{+}(4430) together with the measurements of the Zc+‚Äã(3900)subscriptsuperscriptùëçùëê3900Z^{+}_{c}(3900) (which was measured by BESIII and confirmed by other groups) and also of the Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025), Zc+‚Äã(4025)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and Zc+‚Äã(3885)superscriptsubscriptùëçùëê3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885), reinforced our belief that we are observing multiquark states. What has to be done next? From the experimental side it is necessary to determine unambiguosly the quantum numbers of all these states and eliminate the suspicion that they are mere threshold effects and not real particles. As suggested in Ref.¬†[\refcitetokhenno14], this can be done performing an energy scan in the e+‚Äãe‚àísuperscriptùëísuperscriptùëíe^{+}e^{-} reactions. Moreover, a more refined analysis will allow us to determine whether all these states are really different. From the theoretical side its necessary to focus on the calculation of the decay widths in all the different approaches, since, as we have discussed, the masses are easily obtained by different methods and they are not sufficient to discriminate between different theoretial models. If our present picture of these states survives all these tests and improvements, we will have found multiquark states. This is in itself very interesting! Whether meson molecules, tetraquarks or hadrocharmonium, these are novel objects which will induce a small revolution in our understanding of hadrons.
